posts.cooked:
With search I don‚Äòt find a clear answer:
If a username is deleted, will it ever be recycled or reused by Signal?

Larissa:

will it ever be recycled or reused by Signal?

Yes, but after a while.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Larissa:

recycled or reused by Signal?

this is a slightly misleading wording. if you choose another username or delete your existing one, it is reserved for a short period, but afterwords it‚Äôs no longer reserved and anyone can claim it. it‚Äôs not an active thing, since Signal isn‚Äôt handing out usernames, but rather removing the mark from a hash belonging to a username saying it‚Äôs reserved.
1 week or 1 month???

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
3 days.

rassilon1963:

e, it is reserved for a short period

Would you have any source, how long this short period is?

Happened to me a few weeks ago, that due to a technical problem I deleted my Signal account (did not delete my username before), created a new one a day later with the same phone number, chose a new username, and when I checked a few days later, I saw my old username was taken.

Was it there as ‚Äûghost‚Äú, because I did delete the account and not the name, or did a new person take it?

In general, re-use of a username is a little bit of a problem‚Ä¶

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Larissa:

Would you have any source, how long this short period is?

see literally one reply above.

Larissa:

In general, re-use of a username is a little bit of a problem‚Ä¶

not really, since usernames are meant to be disposable. if they weren‚Äôt discarded you‚Äôd have had to make them less easy to discard, which is problematic since people might not want a rogue sign pointing to their account in the form of a leaked username to be something they can‚Äôt deal with.

rassilon1963:

not really,

I see that a little bit differently.

I might hand out many people my Gmail Address. One day I delete it (to switch to whatever), and from that moment, everyone, who tries to send me an email to my old Gmail Address, is automatically informed: unknown address.
The reuse or recycle of email addresses, which just a very few provider do, was seen as an absolute No-Go from all security experts.

Now, with Signal I have the problem:
I hand out my username to everyone. One day for some reason I delete it, and might not be able to remember a list of people, who possess my old username.

So someone might write me, and since the old username is maybe now possessed by someone else, he might write sensitive information to the wrong person.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Larissa:

One day for some reason I delete it, and might not be able to remember a list of people, who possess my old username.

So someone might write me, and since the old username is maybe now possessed by someone else, he might write sensitive information to the wrong person.

Email and phone numbers are ‚Äúpermanent‚Äù contact methods in that people don‚Äôt change them very often or at all. Signal‚Äôs usernames are made to be disposable.

Once someone has established contact via your username, they won‚Äôt need it again. So if you delete your username and someone else claims it later, it‚Äôs unlikely your contacts would search for you by username again because they‚Äôre already talking to you.

Avitus:

Once someone has established contact via your username, they won‚Äôt need it again. So if you delete your username and someone else claims it later, it‚Äôs unlikely your contacts would search for you by username again because they‚Äôre already talking to you.

Yes, but you forget two scenarios:

  1. I gave my username to people, and they do not contact me immediately, but some months later. During that time, my username changed, and instead of getting a message ‚Äôunknown user‚Äô, they might write someone else. Which could be bad.

  2. Some people - and I am one of them - tend to delete chats, if they need that contact only occasionally, let‚Äôs say every few months. Information was sent and deleted via disappearing messages, and instead of leaving an empty chat, I delete it until next need. So I would need the username again.

No, I think the re-use or recycling (call it as you like) of usernames is a very bad idea. Especially to use them again after 3 days, instead of 3 years.

what if in a custom client I change
Duration.ofDays(3);
to
Duration.ofYears(3);
or
Duration.ofDays(3333);

or similar syntax?
The server will reject your request or ignore the client setting

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Larissa:

During that time, my username changed

if it is very important for you to account for the option of people contacting you months after you give them your contact details, then don‚Äôt change your contact details. so long as you don‚Äôt discard your username it‚Äôs still yours. i for example still use the first Username i created after version 7.0.
but the thing is usernames are intentionally designed to be less permanent and easily discardable. i feel much more comfortable giving out my username knowing if it got somewhere i don‚Äôt want it to be, i can make it out-of-date with at most a few clicks. my phone number also points to my account, but i don‚Äôt give it out that easily, specifically because i know i couldn‚Äôt easily change it.

if you want a more permanent ‚Äúaddress‚Äù in addition to the discardable usernames, you can always give out your phone number and enable discoverability.

Usernames in Signal

in a custom client

the username reservation happens server-side.

Larissa:

Information was sent and deleted via disappearing messages, and instead of leaving an empty chat, I delete it until next need. So I would need the username again.

No, you would just look them up in your contacts again.

Larissa:
  1. I gave my username to people, and they do not contact me immediately, but some months later. During that time, my username changed, and instead of getting a message ‚Äôunknown user‚Äô, they might write someone else. Which could be bad

That‚Äôs a possible situation, but it‚Äôs very unlikely that someone would get the exact same username and discriminator unless you had a very popular one that you let go or if someone was purposefully trying to impersonate you. I think both of those scenarios would be extremely rare, but if that is your threat model then you should take that into consideration and not change your username until everyone you expect to contact you using it has done so. Or give the username out with an expiration: ‚Äúthis is my current username, but after X it will no longer be mine, so don‚Äôt wait until then‚Äù.

they could also choose a more unique username, decreasing the likelihood someone else picks it in the given time frame.

john.01 is probably common and could be taken by someone else.
heavymetalhardcorejohnboy.42069 is unlikely to be taken.

rassilon1963:

i for example still use the first Username i created after version 7.0.
but the thing is usernames are intentionally designed to be less permanent and easily discardable.

Usernames in Signal

consideration and not change your username until everyone you expect to contact

Yes, this is exactly the point. Signal created the usernames to be not really permanent contact information, but can be changed really fast. And I think, not only me, or you (@rassilon1963); basically most people tend to prefer using names for a very long time. So I‚Äôm not sure, whether the concept of this usernames is really right (for example, for long lasting contact information, the usernames should better have no discriminator).

Usernames in Signal

That‚Äôs a possible situation, but it‚Äôs very unlikely that someone would get the exact same username and discriminator unless you had a very popular one

All people I know have very short and simple usernames. So had I.
Things like Anna.01 or John.01. If you delete one of those, they are gone within a few days.
Even people I don‚Äôt know have simple names. Just to give two examples from websites I sometimes visit: Daring fireball from John Gruber, he gives Signal as contact information, his name is gruber.44
Or the blog of Kuketz, who gives kuketzblog.01

I guess those two also created a username to keep it for a very long time (many years).

So I think Signal should rethink the username, and also present it as something, people should keep for a long time.

Usernames in Signal

they could also choose a more unique username, decreasing the likelihood someone else picks it in the given time frame.

john.01 is probably common and could be taken by someone else.
heavymetalhardcorejohnboy.42069 is unlikely to be taken.

Yes, but the problem with this is, that you have to remember your own username (if you meet someone on the street, for example, hey, contact me on Signal, john.01), and someone else has to be able to remember it, too.
Your heavy metal thing would probably get confused. I know maybe 20 people with a username, and they all have something like john.01

Usernames in Signal

No, you would just look them up in your contacts again.

I don‚Äôt know, how does this work? I meet someone with the name John Meyer. He says, contact me on Signal, my username is john.01

We write, and after months I have to write him again, but the chat is deleted. In this case, my contacts would the name, HE chose to use as profile name in Signal, right? Could be TheReallyCoolGuy or something like that.
How would I now it‚Äôs him?

Larissa:

In this case, my contacts would the name, HE chose to use as profile name in Signal, right? Could be TheReallyCoolGuy or something like that.
How would I now it‚Äôs him?

If you are concerned about people changing their profile name you could use the nickname feature to take control of the displayed name yourself.

I‚Äôve also given the ‚Äúkeep somebody‚Äôs username on the shelf and use it later‚Äù use case some thought. How would the other person have to know it‚Äôs actually you when you decide to establish contact with them? In any case you would have to do some mutual verification before sharing anything sensitive.

Larissa:

if you meet someone on the street, for example, hey, contact me on Signal, john.01

but in that case, why wouldn‚Äôt the person just pull their phone out of there pocket? Then again, in such a scenario you don‚Äôt need the username anyway, just have them scan your QR code and boom, chat established.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Larissa:

most people tend to prefer using names for a very long time.

Larissa:

So I think Signal should rethink the username, and also present it as something, people should keep for a long time.

one should‚Äôt speak for most people without data to back it up and that applies to both of us. i don‚Äôt know if most people treat usernames as permanent or as very temporary.
what i do know is there is already a somewhat permanent pointer to one‚Äôs account, in the form of a phone number. and now there‚Äôs another pointer, with the ability to hold on to permanently, but designed in such a way to allow you to throw it away whenever.
to give you a bit more insight about my usage of Signal, i have Discoverability on and i have a username that i don‚Äôt change. that means people can both find me out by my phone and by my username. but i feel more free to hand out my username than my phone number, specifically because in case i need to i can burn the username. i would never post my phone numebr on Fedi, even as a followers-only post. i have however done that with my Signal username.

the middle ground between one-time usernames and permanent usernames is usernames that you can hold on to as long as you want but discard whenever. which is what Signal does now. that is the only way to accommodate as many people from both camps as possible. there is an argument the way usernames are currently designed leans more into the disposable side (i would highly disagree, but there is an argument), however that argument cancels out with the existence of the permanent phone-number pointer.
that is in addition to the fact Signal often specifically caters to privacy minded people, meaning even pure one-time usernames, which they didn‚Äôt opt to, would have fit that vision.

Larissa:

All people I know have very short and simple usernames. So had I.
Things like Anna.01 or John.01. If you delete one of those, they are gone within a few days.
Even people I don‚Äôt know have simple names. Just to give two examples from websites I sometimes visit: Daring fireball from John Gruber, he gives Signal as contact information, his name is gruber.44
Or the blog of Kuketz, who gives kuketzblog.01

and i assume those people won‚Äôt discard their username, because it is important to them. just as a comparison, there are sites warning celebrities not to delete their accounts on X because soneone else would be able to claim it. other examples of things that can be claimed by others if they expire: domain names, and in some cases, email. if a username is important to you, don‚Äôt discard it. (in fact it‚Äôs worse for domain names, since you can lose it while actively using it just by having a credit card expire.)

Larissa:

that you have to remember your own username

that is definitely not as hard as you make it out to be. as XKCD has shown us with passwords, it‚Äôs just a matter of making it long, not extremely complicated. in fact Signal usernames have much lower risk (partly again due to them being disposable) and as such have much lower complexity requirements. your full name and date of birth is very much easy to remember, is very unlikely to be claimed, and is the sort of thing that‚Äôs okay to give to friends. of course that is only an example, but those examples aren‚Äôt too hard to come up with.

Larissa:

We write, and after months I have to write him again, but the chat is deleted.

so let me understand, your scenario is that you contact someone via their username, delete the chat with them since it accomplished its purpose, delete them from your Signal contacts (otherwise you would just be able to contact them again), and months later you remember their username and write to them again assuming they have the same username? and because of that you ask to make usernames less disposable for everyone?

Larissa:

my contacts would the name, HE chose to use as profile name in Signal, right? Could be TheReallyCoolGuy or something like that.
How would I now it‚Äôs him?

@TeeJay82 already addressed this, but i think in this last part you‚Äôre confusing usernames and profile info. usernames are deleted by the client after the message request is approved and profile info is acquired (which is part of the aforementioned discardability design). people can already change their display names as much as they want (something that you see in every chat you have with them, by the way), and which you can override with the nicknames feature. i don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre suggesting profile info should be harder to change also, but if you do, then i think you‚Äôre barking up the wrong tree and that this is a bad idea.
